title: Sync Outlook 365 Signatures to Mobile, Web, & Other Computers

steps.title: You can only sync signatures using the new Outlook and Outlook.com.
steps.content: You can only sync signatures using the new Outlook and Outlook.com. If you switch to the "New Outlook" experience in the desktop app for Windows, signatures you create will be synced to the cloud and available at Outlook.com and other instances of the New Outlook experience. [1] X Research source Similarly, signatures you create using Outlook.com in your browser will sync to the New Outlook desktop app. Unfortunately, it's not possible to automatically sync signatures to the Outlook mobile app or Outlook for Mac, even using New Outlook and Outlook.com. In the future, Microsoft plans to launch signatures , a feature that syncs Outlook signatures across all devices. [2] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Sign in to https://www.outlook.com on your Android, iPhone, or iPad.
steps.content: Sign in to https://www.outlook.com on your Android, iPhone, or iPad. You'll need to use your mobile web browser to do this, not the Outlook mobile app. If you've already created a signature in Outlook.com on your computer, phone, or tablet, you can easily copy it from the web and insert it into the Outlook mobile app . This is the only way to sync your Outlook signature to the mobile Outlook app. After you tap Sign in , the website will try to get you to use the Outlook mobile app instead. Tap Continue to Outlook sign-in to make sure you're logging in through your browser and not the mobile app.

steps.title: Request the desktop version of the website.
steps.content: Request the desktop version of the website. Once you're signed in, you'll need to display your inbox as though you're viewing it on a computer . Otherwise, there's no way to see your email signature. Chrome: Tap the three dots and select Request Desktop Site . Safari: Tap the aA icon and select Request Desktop Website . Samsung Internet: Tap the three-line menu and select Desktop site .

steps.title: Tap the three dots at the top-right ••• .
steps.content: Tap the three dots at the top-right ••• . It's directly to the right of the magnifying glass icon. Since you're viewing the site's desktop version, you might have to swipe left with your finger to see it.

steps.title: Tap Settings (the gear icon).
steps.content: Tap Settings (the gear icon). It's near the bottom of the menu.

steps.title: Go to the "Compose and Reply" area.
steps.content: Go to the "Compose and Reply" area. If you don't see a menu on the left side of the screen, tap the back arrow at the top-left to expand it, then tap Compose and Reply .

steps.title: Select your signature.
steps.content: Select your signature. Any signatures you've created using Outlook.com or Outlook for Windows in "New Outlook" mode will be available to select from the drop-down menu.

steps.title: Highlight your signature and tap Copy.
steps.content: Highlight your signature and tap Copy . To do this, double-tap any of the words in the signature to bring up the selection bars, then drag the bars on either end of the selected word until the entire signature is highlighted. Once completely highlighted, tap Copy .

steps.title: Open the Outlook mobile app and tap your profile photo.
steps.content: Open the Outlook mobile app and tap your profile photo. When you open the Outlook mobile app, you'll see your profile photo (or a gray placeholder) at the page's top-left corner.

steps.title: Tap the gear icon at the bottom-left corner.
steps.content: Tap the gear icon at the bottom-left corner.

steps.title: Tap Signature.
steps.content: Tap Signature . This is near the middle of the men under the "Mail" header. Now you'll see your current mobile signature, which you can replace with the copied one.

steps.title: Delete and replace the signature.
steps.content: Delete and replace the signature. Tap in the box, then delete anything that's there. To paste the copied signature, tap and hold the box and select Paste . You'll now see your Outlook.com signature in the field. Your signature saves instantly—you can now tap the back button and start using your new signature. Since there's no signature syncing for the Outlook mobile apps, if you change your Outlook.com signature, the changes will not sync to the mobile app. You'll also need to make those same changes in the mobile app signature.

steps.title: Switch to New Outlook (if using Outlook for Windows).
steps.content: Switch to New Outlook (if using Outlook for Windows). If you want to use Outlook's new roaming signature feature in Outlook for Windows, you'll need to switch to the new version of Outlook. To do this, click the switch next to "Try the new Outlook" at the top of the Outlook window, then click Switch . When using New Outlook, you can select and use any signatures you've created using Outlook.com or New Outlook on other devices. You can also create signatures in New Outlook that automatically sync to the cloud. For now, these signatures will not sync to the mobile app or Outlook for Mac.

steps.title: Click the gear icon at the top-right.
steps.content: Click the gear icon at the top-right. It's in the bar that runs along the top of the Outlook window.

steps.title: Click the Accounts tab.
steps.content: Click the Accounts tab. Your email account preferences will expand.

steps.title: Click Signatures.
steps.content: Click Signatures . You'll see any existing signatures you've created with New Outlook and/or Outlook.com.

steps.title: Create a new signature.
steps.content: Create a new signature. Click + New signature . Type a name for your signature. Design your signature in the large box. Choose your preferences, such as setting it as your default signature or adding it to replies/forwards. Your signature and preferences will sync automatically to Outlook.com and other instances of New Outlook.

steps.title: Open Outlook on the computer that has the signature.
steps.content: Open Outlook on the computer that has the signature. If you want to use the same Outlook signature from your desktop installation on another computer, you'll need to copy and paste it into a new signature. The easiest way to do this is to send yourself an email from the computer with the correct signature, open that email on the new computer, and then copy that signature into a new signature file. Sending yourself an email will give you a nice clear copy of your signature without any extra characters that's easy to copy and paste.

steps.title: Send yourself an email.
steps.content: Send yourself an email. To make sure your signature is included in the email, click the Insert tab, select Signature , and choose your signature. Address the email to yourself. You don't have to include a subject line or a body if you don't want to.

steps.title: Open the email on your new computer.
steps.content: Open the email on your new computer. On the computer that doesn't have the signature yet, open the Outlook application and click the new message from yourself—you'll see the message and signature in the preview pane.

steps.title: Copy your signature.
steps.content: Copy your signature. To do so, highlight the entire signature with your mouse, then press Ctrl + C (Windows) or Cmd + C (Mac) to copy.

steps.title: Open your email Options (Windows) or Preferences (Mac).
steps.content: Open your email Options (Windows) or Preferences (Mac). Here's how: Windows: Click the File menu, select Options , then click Mail in the left column. Mac: Click the Outlook menu and select Preferences… .

steps.title: Click Signatures.
steps.content: Click Signatures . On Windows, you'll see this under "Compose messages" in the right panel. On a Mac, it's the icon with a pencil and a sheet of paper. [3] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Select an account.
steps.content: Select an account. If multiple accounts are signed in to Outlook, select the account to which you want to connect the signature.

steps.title: Create a new signature.
steps.content: Create a new signature. If you're using Windows, click New . On a Mac, click + . Give the new signature a name similar to the name you used for your old signature, and click OK .

steps.title: Paste the copied signature into the field.
steps.content: Paste the copied signature into the field. To do this, click in the edit box and press Ctrl + V (Windows) or Cmd + V (Mac). You can now make any changes you need to the signature before saving. Any links and photos you copied should copy exactly as they appeared in the original signature, but you might have to make minor adjustments.

steps.title: Click OK (Windows) or close the window (Mac).
steps.content: Click OK (Windows) or close the window (Mac). The signature from your other computer is now added to this computer.
